attributes.title: KBR: Earnings Up, Share Price Down In Value Opportunity
summary: Despite slowing momentum and negative EPS revisions, KBR's fundamentals remain strong, with steady earnings growth and a robust $20.5 billion backlog.
Short-term risks exist due to federal spending cuts, tariffs, and activist investor uncertainty, but these are less relevant for long-term investors.
Wall Street analysts maintain a bullish outlook, with a consensus Buy rating and an average one-year price target significantly above current levels.
I maintain my Buy rating, expecting a 13% price increase in one year as KBR is undervalued and poised for continued earnings growth.

attributes.content:
Investment thesis

On the summary page for KBR, Inc. (KBR), the Seeking Alpha system warns: “KBR is at high risk of performing badly”. If you click to learn why, the system explains that KBR has characteristics “normally associated” with poor future performance.

However, I will argue that this warning is more applicable to short-term traders and less applicable to long-term investors. While the price may be sliding, earnings keep growing.

That suggests a value investing opportunity; I expect the price to rise by just over 13% in one year and maintain my Buy rating.

The system lists two metrics that signal trouble: decelerating momentum and negative EPS revisions.

Momentum

First, this table shows how momentum has fluctuated over the past year, from D to D-, to D+, and then to F in the past four quarters. Clearly, KBR’s performance is lackluster compared to that of the Industrials median:

If you look on the right side of the table, you can see that it has outperformed the sector over the past five years. So performance since November 2024 is an aberration.

The momentum grades reflect the firm’s slumping share price:

As I reported in my January 16, 2025 article, “KBR: Uncertainty Over Activist Investor And Government Spending Cuts,” its share price peaked at $72.02 on November 11, 2024, a few days after the federal election brought in a new administration. Investors became concerned that KBR would be harmed by federal spending cuts by the then new Department of Government Efficiency, or DOGE.

Further uncertainty came in December when Irenic Capital Management, an activist investment firm, reported it had accumulated a 1% stake in the company. Reports suggested Irenic wanted to split up KBR.

As the chart above shows, the price has kept drifting down since November, which is not surprising as the uncertainty about tariffs and spending cuts continue.

Are investor concerns justified? Perhaps, but as KBR President and CEO Stuart Bradie observed on the Q1-2025 earnings call,

KBR, as you know, is a high-end technology and professional services business and does not import our [or] export products as a significant part of our business. Furthermore, we do not procure raw materials, nor do any manufacturing in China.

That said, if our clients experience the cost of material increase due to tariffs, CapEx budgets may be reevaluated. As of now, we are not seeing a material change in customer behavior, but of course continue to monitor a situation.

His comments are backed up by a solid set of fundamentals, as shown in this 10-year chart:

As the chart shows, net income and basic EPS have grown steadily over the past four quarters. Will they continue to grow?

Quite likely, they will. Earnings momentum is strong and likely will remain so.

Negative EPS revisions

As this table from the KBR summary page shows, the number of Down revisions exceeds the number of Up revisions:

When looking at earnings revisions, it's also helpful to check out the ratings provided by the same Wall Street analysts. They have five Strong Buys, one Buy, and three Holds. To put this another way, there are twice as many Buys and Strong Buys as there are Holds—and there are no Sell or Strong Sell ratings.

What’s more, they have an average, one-year price target of $64.63, a 37.25% increase over the July 24 closing price of $47.09. The lowest of the price targets is $54.00, presumably provided by one of the analysts with a Hold rating, which represents a 14.7% increase. Even the lowest of these targets is substantial.

Finally, on this issue, the consensus among the Wall Street analysts is for double-digit normalized earnings growth this year and near double-digit growth next year.

Clearly, we have some form of disconnect here. Negative earnings revisions by Wall Street analysts are rebutted by their own ratings, price targets, and earnings forecasts.

To make sense of the various perspectives on earnings, consider short-term and long-term approaches to investing.

In the short term, let’s say a month to six months, it’s possible the share price could continue falling as uncertainty over tariffs and Irenic linger.

But, in the long term, we should expect KBR’s earnings to grow and push up the share price. This is what management provided in the Q1-2025 earnings report:

For comparison, in fiscal 2024, which ended on January 3, 2025 (as recorded in the Q4-2024 earnings report:

  • Revenue: $7.742 million, versus the 2025 midpoint of $8.9 billion.
  • Adjusted EBITDA: $870 million, versus the 2025 midpoint of $970 million.
  • Adjusted EPS: $3.34 versus the 2025 midpoint of $3.83.
  • Operating cash flows: $462 million, versus the 2025 midpoint of $525 million.

Also adding steam to KBR’s optimistic guidance is another detail listed in the report: backlog and options worth $20.5 billion dollars, down slightly from Q1-2024’s $21.2 billion. If nothing else, this means the company should be busy for at least a couple of years, even if its customers are affected by tariffs or if there is an economic slowdown (bearing in mind that backlog doesn’t necessarily turn into revenue and earnings, but the odds are on KBR’s side).

Obviously, not only does the company expect it will do better this year than last year, but also that it will do much better. Wall Street analysts expect normalized EPS to reach $3.81 for the year, a 14.18% gain over 2024:

The KBR share price

While earnings have risen and are expected to keep rising, the share price has gone in the opposite direction since last November:

When earnings are going up and the price is going down, there may be opportunities for value investors and others. That is confirmed by its major valuation grades:

I believe KBR is current undervalued.

To set a one-year price target, I will use the EPS estimates from Wall Street analysts. Specifically, I will take three quarters of their 2025 estimate of 14.18% (since one quarter is already complete), and one quarter of the 2026 estimate of 9.66%.

That works out to 13.06%, and adding that amount to the July 25 closing price of $47.15 gives us a target of $53.31. Given this significant increase in the share price and bullish earnings situation, I will maintain my Buy rating, and for essentially the same reason. KBR has a significant amount of upside potential, despite the uncertainties that drive the share price.

As noted, the Wall Street analysts have a one-year target of $64.63, an increase of 37.07% increase over the closing price. They have a collective Buy, based on five Strong Buys, one Buy, and three Holds.

One other Seeking Alpha analyst has posted a rating in the past 90 days, a Buy. And the Quant system has a Sell, based on its quantitative concern about momentum and negative net earnings revisions.

Risk factors

Although I believe the Quant system is too heavily reliant on the current share price and negative earnings revisions, it may be correct in both the short term and long term. The share price could continue to slip.

Some of its revenue originates with the federal government, and budget cuts may reduce the number or value of new contracts.

By the end of the first quarter, tariff issues had not affected its costs or it markets. However, management did express concern about its customers being affected by tariffs, and as a result might spend less with KBR.

Tariffs or other economic factors such as interest rates, might drive down demand for its services. A recession or other economy-wide slowdown could affect both its revenue and profitability.

It competes with other large and economically powerful firms, and as a result could lose market share or have its reputation harmed if there are any serious problems or mistakes by its personnel or contractors.

Conclusion

As I have shown, concern about decelerating momentum and negative earnings revisions are of limited value in assessing the future of KBR, Inc.

Shareholders and would-be investors would be better served studying the fundamentals, which strongly suggest continuing increases on the top and bottom lines, backed up by $20.5 billion worth backlog and options.

attributes.bio: Robert F. Abbott has been investing his family’s accounts since 1995, and in 2010 added options, mainly covered calls and collars with long stocks. He is a freelance writer, and his projects include a website that provides information for new and intermediate-level mutual fund investors. A resident of Airdrie, Alberta, Canada, Robert has earned Bachelor of Arts and Master of Business Administration (MBA) degrees.
